lines.text: The flesh is still strong, but the spirit grows weaker by the hour. You know, even if the spirit of adventure should rise up before me and beckon, even in the form of that alluring young woman in the window next door, I'm afraid that all I'll do is clutch my coat a little tighter, mutter something idiotic and run like the devil.
Not before you got her number, I hope?
Probably.
Well, there are two general reactions. One is a kind of solemn stare for the painting.
And the other?
The other is a long, low whistle.
What was mine?
I'm not sure. But I suspect that in another moment or two you might have given a long, low, solemn whistle.

There are only three ways to deal with a blackmailer. You can pay him and pay him and pay him until you're penniless. Or you can call the police yourself and let your secret be known to the world. Or you can kill him.
The streets were dark with something more than night.

[Offering him a drink]
Let's have another.
I should say no, I know, but I haven't the slightest intention of saying it.

[Indicates the painting in the window]
Is it yours?
No. I wish it were. Then I wouldn't have to come over here every so often to watch people's faces.
Is that what you do?
Now and then, when I'm lonely.
We rarely arrest people just for knowing where the body was.
[first lines]

[lecturing]
The Biblical injunction "Thou shalt not kill" is one that requires qualification in view of our broader knowledge of impulses behind homicide. The various legal categories such as first and second degree murder, the various degrees of homicide, manslaughter, are civilized recognitions of impulses of various degrees of culpability. The man who kills in self defense, for instance, must not be judged by the same standards applied to the man who kills for gain.

[In a cautionary tone]
In the District Attorney's office we see what happens to middle-aged men who try acting like colts.
Well, what do you think?

[Distractedly]
THe woman?
You think she's the one?

[Cynically]
I don't know. She's got something on her conscience, but what woman hasn't?
Well? Will you say what you've got to say and get out of here?
Sure. If you didn't hear it, it was on the radio tonight. Another reward for ten thousand dollars for any information leading to the arrest of the murderer of Claude Mazard. You didn't hear it?
And if I had, it wouldn't have meant one thing to me.
Now if you're gonna start claiming you never knew him, you can save your breath. 'Cause I've been tailing him for months, and I've tailed him here many a time.
I don't want to make trouble for anybody. I can, of course, but I don't want to.
[last lines]
Pardon me. Will you give me a light?
No. Oh, no. Thank you indeed. Not for a million dollars.
We've decided she's our dream girl just from that picture.

[Talking abstractly about women and sex]
The flesh is still strong but the spirit grows weaker by the hour.

[Sees Alice Reed for the first time, after just seeing her painting in the window]
I-I couldn't have drunk that much.
30, sir.

[Barges in]
Who are you?

[Stands up]
My name is...

[Runs in from other room]
Frank! Frank, darling, listen to me!
I told you if you ever-
[slaps Alice in the face]
Stop that you fool!

[Runs at Wanley]
Fool, eh?
[Punches Wanley]
